We left Shanghai Monday morning March 25th at 8 o'clock
and arrived at Hankow at 11:30
Then we refueled and
got off
for Chungking•

adjustments and servicing the motors.
radio operator were
to make the first flight to Kweiyang and
return, and
the plan was to have them fly as light as possible so

The weather was bad Wednes-
and therefore the flight was postponed until
Thursday.
In the

Chengtu on the regular plane and
as I write this letter, Friday
morning March
29th we are on our
way back to Chungking•
Tuesday morning we crossed the Yangtze from the opposite
bank where the Palos was
anchored and spent
the day with friends of
One of them, a Mr.
Wu, is a graduate of M.I.T. and built
the Chungking light plant.
He showed us around the city and found
quarters for us.
there is no hotel in Chungking.
We left our bags
at the Bank of Chungking where adjoining the directors room
two rooms for visiting friends.
Ki Chun's friend told us in
recommending these quarters
that we would have the only flush toilet
in Chungking•
The President of the Bank did everything possible to
make us comfortable.
We called on General Yu,
the Vice-Minister of
Communications Tuesday morning and had a long talk with him.
He has
just recently returned from a trip
around the
world and is now on
an inspection trip around China.
He flew up to Chengtu on a special
flight Tuesday afternoon.
call on General
Yu we took a
drive around town - there are only
three streets where autos
- all the rest is by sedan chair.
Then we had Chinese lunch and
in the afternoon we drove out to inspect the road which leads to
Chengtu.
I don't wonder that it is not used much.
Very rough
climbed up over a mountain range there were evidences
all along of land slides - big rocks everywhere on the road,
some
of which our
chauffeur had to remove - others he just dodged.

chow best.

Wednesday afternoon the visibility was not too good but
we flew over to Chengtu and were very fortunate in having perfeet
weather after we
crossed the last range of mountains.
wonderfully rich
sunshine and a
abudless sky.
plain stretched out before us in bright
It is a densely
populated agricul-
section with every inch of land
cultivated much
delta land
the lower Yangtsze.
of the ancient
Like Peking it had its Forbiaden
used as a recreation park.
The great dark massive wall
surrounding
Chengtu is not permitted to crumble away nor is there any talk
about pulling
it down
so that a motor highway can be built around
the city as has been done by
many other cities.
Chengtu has been
attacked many times,
- once it has fallen since I was
there less
two years ago.
Just recently
the Nanking Government has extended its
actual (rather
than nominal) control
to Szechuan
Province and
within the last 30 days the
Central Government (Nanking)
banch of the
Central Bank of
$20,000,000
China and shipped over
to Chungking.
the Province and
Chiang Kai-shek made his first trip
plans to spend a long time in this section
reorganizing the military and
governmental machinery.
at Kweiyang effecting
the reorganization of
that province.
Until
these two provinces have
part of China on the map
but in all other respects completely independent.
They paid
nothing
to the National
treasury and
got nothing from it.
and losing armies have looted and ravished Szechuen for so many years
that the poor
farmers and small merchants live in
constant fear of
little choice of whether
the soldiers are friend

Therefore the well trained disciplined troops of Chiang Kai-shek
which pay for what they take and live in barracks instead of
moving into the homes of the populace have been welcomed and
Szechuen Province should prosper greatly from now on.
Taxes
have been collected through 1974.
These will have to be adjusted
and a better provincial government organized.
I do not believe
that any
Szechuen war lord will again successfully defy Nanking
because of the latter's air force.
The same statement is true of
Kweichow Province.
Formerly it was quite impossible to successfully carry
out a punitive expedition against any
Szechuen war lord,
at least
without terrific losses and costs.
Now airplanes can attaok in
a few hours and at only a nominal cost.
We returned to Chungking on Friday March 29th and.
started
for Kweiyang on Saturday but had to turn back on account of clouds
closing the
mountain tops and passes.
We will try again on
Sunday
and I'll tell you about that part of the trip in another
letter - this one is already
too long•
ever
Harolo
